cards.front: State the capacitor voltage continuity property.
cards.back: If i(t) is bounded in [t_a, t_b], then v_C(T⁺) = v_C(T⁻) for any T in that interval. Capacitor voltage cannot jump with finite current.

cards.front: State the inductor current continuity property.
cards.back: If v_L(t) is bounded in [t_a, t_b], then i_L(T⁺) = i_L(T⁻). Inductor current cannot jump with finite voltage. Dual of capacitor property.

cards.front: Define the unit impulse function δ(t).
cards.back: δ(t) = 0 for t ≠ 0, singular at t = 0, and ∫₋ε¹ε² δ(t)dt = 1 for any ε₁,ε₂ > 0. Infinite height, zero width, unit area.

cards.front: What produces an impulse of current in a capacitor?
cards.back: A step (discontinuous) change in voltage: i = C·dv/dt → ∞ when dv/dt → ∞. Arises when voltage source is connected directly (zero resistance) to capacitor.

cards.front: What does a current impulse Aδ(t) do to a capacitor?
cards.back: Produces a voltage step of magnitude A/C. The impulse deposits charge A instantaneously: ΔV = A/C from q = CV.

cards.front: How to find initial conditions at a switching instant?
cards.back: 1. Find v_C(0⁻) or i_L(0⁻) from the old circuit. 2. Apply continuity: v_C(0⁺) = v_C(0⁻), i_L(0⁺) = i_L(0⁻). 3. Use these as initial conditions in the new circuit.

cards.front: Can resistor voltage jump at a switching instant?
cards.back: YES. Only state variables (v_C, i_L) are continuous. Resistor voltages, capacitor currents, and other quantities CAN jump discontinuously at switching instants.

cards.front: Why do inductors cause arcing when switches open?
cards.back: i_L must remain continuous, so di/dt is enormous when current is forced to zero quickly. v = L·di/dt → very large, creating an arc across the switch gap.
If circuit N has unique solution v̂(t) at port, the port element can be replaced by source v̂(t) (or î(t)) without affecting rest of circuit, provided substituted circuit also has unique solution.

cards.front: Relationship between impulse and step functions?
cards.back: δ(t) = d/dt[u(t)] and u(t) = ∫₋∞ᵗ δ(τ)dτ. The impulse is the derivative of the step; the step is the integral of the impulse.
